qas.question: What do armies tend to have in depth?
Angara and Patriot are two examples of what type of system?
Stinger and Igla are two examples of what type of system?
What kind of platform are Roland and SA-8 Gecko?

context: Armies typically have <a0_0>air defence<a0_0/> in depth, from integral MANPADS such as the RBS 70, Stinger and Igla at <a2_0>smaller force levels<a2_0/> up to <a1_0>army-level missile defence systems<a1_0/> such as Angara and Patriot. Often, the high-altitude long-range missile systems force aircraft to fly at low level, where anti-aircraft guns can bring them down. As well as the small and large systems, for effective air defence there must be intermediate systems. These may be deployed at regiment-level and consist of platoons of self-propelled anti-aircraft platforms, whether they are <a3_0>self-propelled anti-aircraft guns<a3_0/> (SPAAGs), integrated air-defence systems like Tunguska or <a4_0>all-in-one surface-to-air missile platforms<a4_0/> like Roland or SA-8 Gecko.
